awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports development of theory and tools to improve the coordination of distributed teams, i.e., groups of geographically-dispersed individuals working together over time towards a common goal. The separation of distributed work generally makes it harder for team members to work together effectively. However, when work products are shared via a computer system, team participants can see the work produced by remote colleagues as easily as from those who are local, and the work can provide information to support team coordination. Specifically, prior research suggests that free/libre open source software (FLOSS) developers use the software code they are developing as a basis for coordinating their work, a phenomenon known as stigmergic coordination. Stigmergic coordination can be more effective and efficient than coordination through explicit discussion, so there could be benefits if it can be used more broadly. The goal of the project is to study FLOSS developers to understand how stigmergic coordination works and to develop a system to enable its use in other settings. 

To achieve these goals, this study will be done in two phases: first identifying the socio-technical affordance enabling stigmergic coordination in FLOSS development teams (as exemplars of distributed teams) and similar settings, and second, testing the emerging theoretical understanding by implementing and assessing a system to support stigmergic coordination of distributed work in a new domain. The study will have several expected intellectual contributions. First, the empirical study should provide evidence for (or possibly against) stigmergic coordination as a mode of coordination in distributed work. As well, the study will identify possible negative outcomes from the use of stigmergy. More importantly, the study will identify socio-technical affordances that enable the use of stigmergy. Knowing these affordances will provide a basis for designing shared-work systems that support stigmergy. They will also help in understanding the possibilities and limits on the transfer of coordination mechanisms from open content creation teams to other domains. The study will have several broader impacts. First, being able to implement a novel mode of coordination could be transformative for the conduct of online work and computer-supported work more generally. Second, if it seems that reliance on stigmergy is off-putting for certain potential group participants (women in particular), then the project can study how that happens and potentially mitigate the huge gender gap currently observed in FLOSS development participation in particular and in online groups more generally. The software system to be developed will be released as open source for use in future research (thus contributing to the infrastructure for research) and potentially for use by distributed workers (thus potentially benefiting society).

por.por_cntn:
The study developed theory and tools to improve the coordination of distributed teamwork and derived implications for collective work more generally. The study built on prior work suggesting that free/libre open source software (FLOSS) developers use the code they are developing as a basis for coordinating their work, a phenomenon known as stigmergic coordination. The idea motivating the project was that when work products are shared via a computer system, team participants can see the artefacts produced by remote colleagues as easily as from those who are locally situated, and these artefacts can provide information to support team coordination.

This study therefore addressed the following research question:

  1. How do distributed teams use shared work artefacts to support coordination of their work?
  2. Specifically, what socio-technical affordances enable stigmergic coordination in such teams?

To answer these questions, a two-phase study was conducted: first identifying the socio-technical affordance enabling stigmergic coordination in FLOSS development teams (as exemplars of distributed teams) and similar settings, and second, testing the emerging theoretical understanding by implementing and assessing a system to support stigmergic coordination of distributed work in a new domain, namely data science.

Our theoretical analysis in the first phase identified three affordances needed to enable stigmergic coordination: visibility of contributions to a shared work product, legibility or recognizability of the purpose of a contribution and combinability of different contributions to compose the result. For data science, a key problem was recognizability and combinability. For instance, a team can share an R script (R is a commonly-used data science tool) using a shared editor like Google Docs or codeshare.io. However, it is difficult for a team member to know what to make of code shared by another team member or to use it as part of their own analysis.

The system we developed in the second phase is named MIDST, the Modular Interactive Data Science Tool. MIDST implements support for the identified affordances by structuring the R code as a workflow (see Fig 1). This representation promotes the modularity of the solution by dividing it into blocks with clear data flows from one part of the analysis to another. Team members create their own code in blocks (see Fig 2) and can execute a block or the whole workflow. When their code is working, they can push it to other team members, who can then pull the updates when they're ready to incorporate the changes.

Our plan for system assessment was a controlled experiment comparing teams using MIDST to teams using RStudio. We used the system in the fall of 2019 with 18 teams in 3 face-to-face sections of an introductory data science class (we collected data from 9 teams using RStudio as a comparison). In the 1st quarter of 2020, we used the system with 6 teams in 2 sections of a distance version of the same course, with 7 teams in 2 sections that used RStudio.

Unexpectedly we found that only about 2/3 of the teams assigned to the MIDST condition actually used its features for supporting coordination. However, the teams that did use those features seemed to be able to coordinate stigmergically. An analysis of how the teams spent time in group meetings found that the teams using MIDST seemed to be able to shift directly to working on the code rather than on coordination. MIDST teams reported (on a survey) fewer problems with coordination and code sharing. The quality of the product of the teams who used MIDST was higher than that of teams who used RStudio, which in turn was higher than teams in the MIDST condition who didn't actually use the tool.

We carried out a second experiment on the impacts of MIDST on code modularity with 93 students in 4 sections of the course. Students completed 4 assignments in R. All students did the first two assignments in RStudio; 42 students in two of the four sections continued to use RStudio for the final two assignments while the students in the other two sections used MIDST. The second experiment showed that students using only RStudio struggled to create modular code (operationalized as using functions), while students using MIDST did create modules. We have also examined the impact on the reusability of code: an informal assessment found that students had trouble using code written by others, but could easily rerun a MIDST workflow.

In summary, stigmergic coordination seems to be a useful mechanism for groups, particularly distributed groups. In addition to the work creating MIDST for data science, we have analyzed the use of stigmergy in settings such as FLOSS and Wikipedia, suggesting the generality of the mechanism.
